Award.AwardTitle: Synthetic Biology Open Language (SBOL) Workshop to be held in Boston, MA in March 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Standards for data exchange are critical to the development of any field. They enable researchers and practitioners to exchange information reliably; apply a variety of tools to their problems, and reproduce scientific results. This is a project to support a workshop on this topic in March, 2016 to be held in Boston, Massachusetts. The meeting is organized by the Standards network (SBOL), . The request if for participant costs to enable students and junior scientist to attend the meeting. They will learn valuable lessons in the importance of research and tool standardization and the impact of a community-wide effort. This effort is essential for areas of systems and synthetic biology and translational research to become seamless.

The meetings will specifically explore data exchange standards for biology to enable researchers and practitioners to exchange information reliably, apply a variety of tools to their problems, and reproduce scientific results. The discussion will center, among others, on the systems biology markup language (SBML) for mathematical modeling, the biological pathways exchange language (BioPaX) for describing pathways, the systems biology graphical notation (SBGN) for visual representations, and the synthetic biology open language(SBOL) for describing biological designs. While synthetic biology data exchange has many unique requirements, there are also many overlapping goals such as the need to construct mathematical models, describe pathways, and provide visual representations. Therefore, enabling the sharing of tools and other infrastructure will be generally beneficial. Likewise, other communities will benefit from renewed discussions around data exchange and synthetic biology's unique process of forward engineering living systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided partial travel support for 7 students and postdoctoral fellows to attend SBOL 14 Workshop in Boston, MA, Utah in March 14-16, 2016 (http://sbolstandard.org/meetings/sbol-14-workshop-in-boston/).  This event served as one of our two bi-annual meetings to discuss the Synthetic Biology Open Language (SBOL) data standard.  The goal of this event was to discuss and work on documentation, software infrastructure, and workflows related to this data and visualization standard.  

During the morning of the first day, software developers were invited to demonstrate their software tools, and afterwards we discussed compliance testing for these tools and how to establish design workflows enabled by SBOL. The afternoon was a hacking session where provided support for developers, improved the SBOL standard webpage (sbolstandard.org), develop compliance documentation, and began collecting examples.  During the morning of the second day, we discussed minor updates to the specificaiton for 2.0.1 and larger proposals for 2.1.0.  The afternoon was another hacking session where SBOL 2.0.1 specification writing took place and more edits to the 2.1.0 proposals and the webpage, as well as discussions for SBOL Visual 2.0.  The morning of the third day was a group discussion on SBOL Visual 2.0.  The afternoon was spent finalizing the SBOL 2.0.1 specification, various larger proposals, and website improvements.


This grant was instrumental to the success of this meeting.  Many of the people working on standard development are students and postdocs that either volunteer their time or have limited resources for travel. Without this grant, it would have been prohibitively expensive for many of the participants to attend. This was a great experience for the students and postdocs enabling them to share their work and interact with the larger community, and contribute to the next versions of these standards.
